t: Proverbs 16
The*pn plans of the heart belong to man, but*ld the answer of the tongue is from the Lord.*s
All*ln the ways of a man are pure in his own eyes, but*ld the Lord*s weighs the spirit.
Commit*ln your work to the Lord,*s and*ld your plans will be established.
The*ln Lord*s has made everything for its purpose, even*ld the wicked for the day of trouble.
Everyone*ln who is arrogant in heart is an abomination to the Lord;*s be*ld assured, he will not go unpunished.
By*ln steadfast love and faithfulness iniquity is atoned for, and*ld by the fear of the Lord*s one turns away from evil.
When*ln a man’s ways please the Lord,*s he*ld makes even his enemies to be at peace with him.
Better*ln is a little with righteousness than*ld great revenues with injustice.
The*ln heart of man plans his way, but*ld the Lord*s establishes his steps.
An*ln oracle is on the lips of a king; his*ld mouth does not sin in judgment.
A*ln just balance and scales are the Lord’s;*s all*ld the weights in the bag are his work.
It*ln is an abomination to kings to do evil, for*ld the throne is established by righteousness.
Righteous*ln lips are the delight of a king, and*ld he loves him who speaks what is right.
A*ln king’s wrath is a messenger of death, and*ld a wise man will appease it.
In*ln the light of a king’s face there is life, and*ld his favor is like the clouds that bring the spring rain.
How*ln much better to get wisdom than gold! To*ld get understanding is to be chosen rather than silver.
The*ln highway of the upright turns aside from evil; whoever*ld guards his way preserves his life.
Pride*ln goes before destruction, and*ld a haughty spirit before a fall.
It*ln is better to be of a lowly spirit with the poor than*ld to divide the spoil with the proud.
Whoever*ln gives thought to the word will discover good, and*ld blessed is he who trusts in the Lord.*s
The*ln wise of heart is called discerning, and*ld sweetness of speech increases persuasiveness.
Good*ln sense is a fountain of life to him who has it, but*ld the instruction of fools is folly.
The*ln heart of the wise makes his speech judicious and*ld adds persuasiveness to his lips.
Gracious*ln words are like a honeycomb, sweetness*ld to the soul and health to the body.
There*ln is a way that seems right to a man, but*ld its end is the way to death.
A*ln worker’s appetite works for him; his*ld mouth urges him on.
A*ln worthless man plots evil, and*ld his speech is like a scorching fire.
A*ln dishonest man spreads strife, and*ld a whisperer separates close friends.
A*ln man of violence entices his neighbor and*ld leads him in a way that is not good.
Whoever*ln winks his eyes plans dishonest things; he*ld who purses his lips brings evil to pass.
Gray*ln hair is a crown of glory; it*ld is gained in a righteous life.
Whoever*ln is slow to anger is better than the mighty, and*ld he who rules his spirit than he who takes a city.
The*ln lot is cast into the lap, but*ld its every decision is from the Lord.*s
